stream_context.summary: Kaze works on a desert pyramid level for 'Return to Yoshi's Island'. After identifying major design flaws in his initial maze-like layout, he scraps it and, based on stream feedback, begins creating a new concept centered around a multi-story room with interconnected tunnels and instant warps. The stream covers this entire design pivot, from problem identification to modeling the new layout.

development_findings.summary: Kaze completely scrapped the initial layout for a pyramid maze level after identifying fundamental gameplay, camera, and navigation flaws, and started over with a new concept based on a central room with instant warps.
development_findings.quote: Sucks I did all this but most of this is reusable. So it's fine. It's fine. It's fine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discovered a new, performance-free technique to add vertex coloring to Mario's model, which he used to add details like a shine on his shoes.
development_findings.quote: I realized I can use the blend mode and set cycle 1 alpha to just shade color and effectively vertex color him that way by lerping into black.

development_findings.summary: The project is nearing completion of its main content, with the current level being Course 14 of a planned 15. Kaze anticipates finishing main content in 2025, to be followed by beta testing and bug fixing.
Kaze rejected a more traditional 'central hub' design for the pyramid level because it felt too common, opting for a more experimental and potentially confusing design to create a unique experience.
development_findings.quote: I wanted to try something new.

development_findings.summary: The camera is a major concern in the tight corridors of the pyramid level, and Kaze is actively designing around it to ensure it's not 'awful'.
Kaze uses a script called 'fast64' to export models and levels directly from Blender into a format the N64 engine can use.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that because the game is free, the initial levels must be exceptionally high quality to capture and retain player interest, as there is no financial investment to make them stick with it.
context_findings.quote: The fact that this game doesn't cost money in a way that's really bad news for us. If you have a paid video game you have an investment... we're getting this game for free so if the first level is not good you're not invested, right?

context_findings.summary: Kaze is mentally preparing for a potential Nintendo takedown, expressing more frustration with the anticipated smug community reaction than the takedown itself, which he views as a calculated risk.
context_findings.quote: I know exactly that when I release it and there is a copyright take down there's gonna be so many people going like wow should have not told people about the game... It's like yes I knew this was going to happen but I didn't know it was going to happen. The fuck is your point? It still sucks. It was a calculated risk.

context_findings.summary: Kaze maintains a frugal lifestyle despite his success, stating he never buys anything and feels many people buy things out of an inability to find happiness otherwise.
context_findings.quote: I still just live like I make $7,000 a year.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's game design philosophy is heavily influenced by Majora's Mask, prioritizing the journey and world interaction leading up to a major objective over a simple sequence of challenges.
context_findings.quote: I've recently decided that Majora's Mask is the true Zelda game by far... in Majora's Mask it's not just so much about doing the dungeons themselves it's about the journey to get into the dungeon.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with the unsolicited integration of AI into software like Notepad, speculating it's driven by companies hoping to capture a user base for the 'next big thing' rather than providing actual utility.
context_findings.quote: The AI situation is a little bizarre to me. It seems very evident to me that no one wants it, but somehow it keeps being added to things.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shares a personal anecdote about a disagreement with his wife, Zeina, over who was at fault for his water pitcher breaking, stemming from their different uses of the kitchen sink.

biobak.summary: Kaze trusts Biobak to fix placeholder or rough texture work, indicating a clear division of labor where Kaze implements geometry and Biobak handles the final texture art.
biobak.quote: I know it looks poofy right now but Biobak said it's gonna move it so I'm not worrying about it for now.

zeina.summary: Kaze acknowledges that having a baby has been a significantly larger life change for Zeina, who is a stay-at-home mom, than for himself.
zeina.quote: For me, as my wife is mainly caring for the child, she's a stay at home mom. So for me, it was just work before and it's mostly just work after. So it's going to have been a much, much bigger change for her.

zeina.summary: Kaze tells a story about Zeina wanting to give Halloween candy to neighbor kids, which resulted in an awkward exchange where they were mistaken for trick-or-treaters and gave the children extremely spicy Takis.
A minor domestic disagreement between Kaze and Zeina over the use of the kitchen sink led to Kaze's water pitcher breaking.

key_stories.title: Pyramid Level Redesign
key_stories.summary: During the stream, Kaze realized his initial pyramid maze design was fundamentally flawed and frustrating. After taking community feedback, he scrapped the entire layout and pivoted to a completely new concept built around a central hub with instant warps, which he believes solves the core issues while remaining interesting.
key_stories.challenge: The initial design for the pyramid level was a confusing maze that was frustrating to navigate. Players would likely miss a red coin and have to repeat a long, tedious climb with poor camera angles.
key_stories.process: After identifying the flaws in his original layout, Kaze took suggestions from the stream chat. He brainstormed a new structure involving a central room, sketched out the connections, and then decisively deleted the old geometry to start fresh on the new concept.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze adopted a new design centered around a multi-story hub with interconnected tunnels and instant warps. This new concept is more manageable for the player while still being interestingly complex, and he began modeling it immediately.
key_stories.key_quote: This is a really dangerous design, too... Maybe I'm asking too much of the player.

key_stories.title: The Broken Pitcher Incident
key_stories.summary: Kaze shared a personal story about how his water pitcher broke. The incident stemmed from a humorous conflict with his wife, Zeina, over their different uses for the kitchen sink, and they still disagree on who was at fault.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze's water pitcher broke, leaving him without his preferred way to stay hydrated while working.
key_stories.process: Kaze explained that he likes to fill his pitcher from the sink, but Zeina often stores dirty dishes in it. While trying to fill the pitcher by balancing it on the edge of the dish-filled sink, it fell and broke.
key_stories.outcome: The pitcher remains broken, and the couple has a lighthearted, unresolved disagreement about who is to blame. It reveals a small, humanizing glimpse into their domestic life and Kaze's specific habits.
key_stories.key_quote: So the situation I just described do you think it was my fault that it broke or it was Zeina's? We're not a hundred percent in agreement over whose fault it is quite yet.

key_stories.title: The Halloween Candy Incident
key_stories.summary: Kaze recounted an awkward Halloween story where he and Zeina tried to give candy to neighbor kids but were mistaken for trick-or-treaters. The situation was made worse because the candy they gave away was extremely spicy, leading to a cringeworthy and memorable interaction.
key_stories.challenge: On Halloween, Zeina wanted to give candy to neighbor children, but no trick-or-treaters came to their house.
key_stories.process: Kaze and Zeina took their infant and a bag of candy to the neighbors' house. The babysitter, seeing them with a baby, misunderstood their intent and gave them candy. Compounding the awkwardness, the candy they gave in return was extremely hot Takis.
key_stories.outcome: The interaction was awkward and Kaze humorously worries they may have seemed like they were trying to get free candy or, worse, poison the neighbors' children with the extremely spicy snacks.
key_stories.key_quote: So how cringe was this interaction? How much aura did I lose?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Biobak would fix a texture he was working on. This implies a workflow where Kaze creates placeholder assets that are later finalized by Biobak.
questions: Can you walk me through the typical asset pipeline? For example, when you need a new graphic, how is that communicated to Biobak?
How do you handle feedback and revisions on art assets? Is there a formal process or is it more conversational?
How much creative freedom does Biobak have in interpreting your initial blockouts and ideas?

open_questions.context: Kaze has clearly thought a lot about the risk of a Nintendo takedown and has a plan for a copyright-free trailer. He seems resigned to the possibility but also defiant.
questions: You called the risk of a takedown 'calculated'. What does that calculation look like for you? What are the pros that outweigh that major con?
Beyond the frustration with community comments, what would the emotional impact of a takedown be on you and the team after years of work?
Have you considered or prepared for different scenarios, like a takedown notice versus a full cease and desist? Are there any 'safe' ways to distribute the game?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that becoming parents has been a much bigger life change for Zeina, a stay-at-home mom, than for him. Both are contributors to the project.
questions: How has becoming parents changed the dynamic of your creative collaboration on the game?
How do you balance project deadlines and creative work with the new responsibilities of family life?
Has Zeina's role or workload on the project shifted since the baby was born? How do you navigate that?

open_questions.topic: Majora's Mask Design Philosophy in Practice
open_questions.context: Kaze passionately praised Majora's Mask for focusing on the 'journey to the dungeon' rather than just the dungeons themselves, and identified this as his core design philosophy.
questions: Besides this new pyramid level, can you point to another level or moment in 'Return to Yoshi's Island' that is a direct result of this 'Majora's Mask' philosophy?
How do you design a 'journey' that is engaging without feeling like padding before the 'real' challenge?
Was there ever a time this philosophy led you down a path that didn't work and you had to pull back to a more traditional design?
